question: Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for medial rotation of the shoulder?
short_explanation: The subscapularis is a key medial rotator of the shoulder.
long_explanation: The subscapularis muscle originates on the subscapular fossa and inserts on the lesser tubercle of the humerus. It plays a primary role in medial (internal) rotation of the shoulder.
clinical_application: Massage therapists can target the subscapularis during shoulder mobility treatments, especially in cases of restricted internal rotation.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 5th Ed.

question: Which movement pattern represents shoulder medial rotation?
options: Rotating the arm to touch the opposite shoulder
Raising the arm sideways to shoulder height
Swinging the arm behind the back
Rotating the arm outward away from the body
correctAnswer: Rotating the arm to touch the opposite shoulder
short_explanation: Medial rotation turns the humerus inward toward the midline.
long_explanation: Medial (internal) rotation of the shoulder occurs when the humerus rotates around its axis toward the body's midline, such as when placing a hand on the opposite shoulder.
clinical_application: This movement is assessed during shoulder range-of-motion testing and can be restricted in conditions like adhesive capsulitis.
source_reference: Principles of Anatomy and Physiology, Tortora & Derrickson

question: Which of these muscles assists in shoulder medial rotation?
short_explanation: Pectoralis major contributes to medial rotation of the shoulder.
long_explanation: In addition to its role in adduction and flexion, the pectoralis major helps medially rotate the humerus by pulling it toward the body's center.
clinical_application: Massage techniques targeting the pectoralis major can relieve tension that limits internal shoulder movement.
source_reference: Muscles: Testing and Function, Kendall et al.

question: Which muscle is NOT involved in shoulder medial rotation?
short_explanation: The infraspinatus is a lateral rotator of the shoulder.
long_explanation: The infraspinatus externally rotates the humerus. It works antagonistically to medial rotators like the subscapularis, pectoralis major, and latissimus dorsi.
clinical_application: Identifying opposing muscles helps massage therapists plan treatment for imbalances and pain syndromes.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 5th Ed.

question: What is the role of teres major in shoulder movement?
options: Medial rotation and adduction of the humerus
correctAnswer: Medial rotation and adduction of the humerus
short_explanation: Teres major medially rotates and adducts the humerus.
long_explanation: Teres major is located on the posterior scapula and assists in medial rotation, adduction, and extension of the humerus. It works with latissimus dorsi during shoulder motions.
clinical_application: Massage therapy for the posterior shoulder should include teres major when addressing internal rotation issues.
source_reference: Muscles: Testing and Function, Kendall et al.

question: Shoulder medial rotation primarily occurs in which plane of movement?
short_explanation: Medial rotation occurs in the transverse plane.
long_explanation: Medial (internal) rotation of the shoulder involves rotation around the longitudinal axis of the humerus within the transverse plane, especially when the arm is abducted at 90 degrees.
clinical_application: Understanding movement planes helps therapists assess and address joint dysfunctions accurately.
source_reference: Principles of Anatomy and Physiology, Tortora & Derrickson

question: Which of the following positions best demonstrates active shoulder medial rotation?
options: Placing the hand behind the back
Rotating the arm away from the body
correctAnswer: Placing the hand behind the back
short_explanation: Placing the hand behind the back demonstrates active medial rotation.
long_explanation: Medial rotation is demonstrated when the arm rotates inward, such as when placing the dorsum of the hand on the lower back (as in reaching for a wallet).
clinical_application: This movement is often restricted in frozen shoulder or subscapularis tightness.
source_reference: Muscles: Testing and Function, Kendall et al.

question: Which nerve innervates the subscapularis muscle involved in shoulder medial rotation?
short_explanation: The upper and lower subscapular nerves innervate the subscapularis.
long_explanation: The subscapularis is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves (branches of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus), allowing it to perform medial rotation of the shoulder.
clinical_application: Knowledge of innervation supports assessments for nerve impingement and muscular dysfunction.

question: Which muscle group collectively contributes to shoulder medial rotation?
options: Subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major
Teres minor, trapezius, rhomboids, serratus anterior
correctAnswer: Subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major
short_explanation: Subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major all contribute.
long_explanation: These muscles—subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major—work together to produce medial rotation of the shoulder. They attach at different points on the humerus but all rotate it inward.
clinical_application: Stretching and releasing this group is essential in treatment of postural syndromes and rotator cuff dysfunctions.
source_reference: Muscles: Testing and Function, Kendall et al.

question: Tightness in which of the following muscles can restrict shoulder external rotation and bias medial rotation?
short_explanation: Tight pectoralis major can restrict external rotation and promote medial rotation.
long_explanation: When the pectoralis major is shortened, it pulls the humerus inward, biasing the shoulder toward internal (medial) rotation and limiting external mobility.
clinical_application: Massage therapists often release the pectoralis major to improve range of motion in clients with postural deviations or rounded shoulders.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 5th Ed.
